div1.p:
My dear Dr. Hench - I am writing on this rather
imposing stationery, as it seems to be all that is at
hand, except some rather small note paper, which
dont file so well. I was pleased to get your very
appreciative telegram and to know that the “Contract”
arrived with glass unbroken. I am sending you
some old letters that I came across the other day
in looking thru the file to get some data for a
young woman from Vassar who wants to write a
short life of Walter Reed and was sent to me by
his son Gen. Walter Lawrence Reed. I dont think you
have seen them and there may be something in
those from Agramonte which may be of interest. How
the letter press copies of the letters from Gen. Sternberg
got into my file I dont remember. Probably they were
left in the personal file and Mr Jones brought them
to me to see if they were of any value.
AC
K
Mr. Hagedoon's quotation from Gen. Frank McCoy is of
interest. Hagedoons was writing the life of Gen. Leo-
nard Wood in 1929 and of course wanted to know
all about the yellow fever episode. The chronology
record was evidently prepared for his use. I am much
puzzled over McCoys statement that Gen. Wood told
his aids & personal staff on Oct. 9 of the definite solu-
tion of the Y.F. problem. I did not think he knew
about it until Reed told him at the interview when
I was present on Oct 12th. It may be that Gorgas
had told him something of what was going on out
at Marianao, but Gorgas certainly did not believe
at that time in the mosquito theory, see my note
of my talk with him just before leaving for work on Jan 30
1901 in this memo. I have verified the fact that Gen.
Wood's birthday was Oct. 9 and my diary positively fixes
the date of Reed's & my interview with him as Oct. 12.
Now by your energy and devotion to the quest of
truth you have come to know more than anyone in
your generation, perhaps than any one alive, as to the
facts. I hope therefore that you will constitute your-
self the guardian of the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor
and see to it that no name of any other person
is intruded thereon by Congress. There have been a
number of persistent claimants but none of them
comply with the requirements originally prescribed
and some have been absolutely without merit.

The last and rankest effort, I think I wrote
you about. There was a nice old doctor named
Poucher who had been for a few months a volunteer
surgeon in the Spanish war in the N.Y. Vols.
He never got to Cuba or saw a case of Yellow
Fever except perhaps some convalescents from
Santiago who he may have treated in a hospital
near Montauk Point in the summer of 1898.
Well he got old & lost his practice and his friends
told Rep. Hamilton Fish that something ought to be
done for him. So what does Fish do but introduce
a bill to have his name inserted in the act creating
the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor to come just after the
name of John J. Moran, altho he did not do
any of the acts recited in the Bill H. R. 13060
approved Feb. 28, 1929. I think that a protest who made
at the cynical immorality of such a proposition
AC
K
4
but it shows what sort of things may happen
if some one is not on guard. I asked Colonel
now Brig. Gen. (temp.) A. G. Love Med. corps to look out for
this, and inclose you a copy of the answer I
had from him. But he retires next month
and I dont know who will be on guard. They
are so swamped with work now that anything
may happen. I have forgotten just what the
ground of Lambert's claim was, that Gen. Love
refers to in his letter, but I think like Dr.
Roger Post Ames he just looked after & cared for
yellow fever cases but was not himself an
experimental case, and contributed nothing to
the advancement of science.

You can keep these letters if you wish - I think
you will make a better disposition of them
than if I keep them.
